Award.AbstractNarration:
New Frontiers in Nuclear Astrophysics can be opened with neutrinos, which escape from dense and distant regions, revealing the microphysics, power mechanisms, and dynamics of astrophysical sources. In turn, the extreme physical conditions of such sources probe untested ranges of neutrino properties, advancing knowledge of the weak and possible new interactions. The theoretical projects supported by this award use neutrinos and other new messengers to attack long-standing questions in nuclear astrophysics, weak interactions, and especially their connections. The primary focus is on the Diffuse Supernova Neutrino Background, the flux of neutrinos and antineutrinos from all core collapses in the universe, a guaranteed source that is near detection. A secondary focus is on prospecting for new neutrino sources and working to move them to the detected or guaranteed category.

The interdisciplinary work of these projects connects central topics in nuclear physics to frontier research in astrophysics, cosmology, and particle physics. It also connects theoretical efforts to experimental and observational efforts ranging from underground laboratories to satellite surveys. Graduate students and postdocs participating in this research will thus receive training in forefront interdisciplinary topics relevant to present and planned investments in experimental facilities. To maximize broader impacts, the proposed work includes outreach based on integrated efforts in research, mentoring, teaching, and service, including with under-served populations, especially the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New Frontiers in Nuclear Astrophysics can be opened with neutrinos, which escape from dense and distant regions of the universe, revealing the dynamics and power mechanisms of astrophysical objects.  In turn, the extreme physical conditions of these objects probe untested ranges of neutrino properties, advancing knowledge of the weak interactions and possible new forces.

For the intellectual-merit component of this project, PI Beacom led studies using neutrinos as new astrophysical messengers, probing longstanding questions in nuclear astrophysics and related fields.  The primary focus was on the Diffuse Supernova Neutrino Background (DSNB), a guaranteed but not-yet-detected flux of neutrinos and antineutrinos from all past core-collapse supernovae.  The secondary focus was on prospecting for new astrophysical neutrino sources and working to enhance their detectability, as well as developing the consequences when they were detected.  The research results of the project were documented through publications in peer-reviewed journals.

For the broader-impacts component of this project, PI Beacom trained graduate students and postdocs in research and career skills; led cross-disciplinary research that connected the planned work to new topics; carried out an extensive program of outreach to the public, including with the Deaf, Hard of Hearing, and other underserved populations; among other activities.  The intellectual-merit work was closely integrated with the broader-impacts work.  An example of an outreach activity is Beacom's talk at TEDx OhioStateUniversity 2015, for which a video is available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6eMdixkoRI (it has been accurately captioned to increase accessibility).
